{{Multiple issues| {{primary sources|date=January 2012}} {{original research|date=January 2012}} }} {{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Epilepsy-intellectual disability in females | image = | caption = | pronounce = | field = | synonyms = EIEE9, EFMR, GEF+ syndrome, epilepsy-intellectual disability in females,<ref name="Stevenson 2012">{{cite journal |vauthors=Stevenson RE, Holden KR, Rogers RC, Schwartz CE |title=Seizures and X-linked intellectual disability |journal=Eur J Med Genet |volume=55 |issue=5 |pages=307–12 |date=May 2012 |pmid=22377486 |pmc=3531238 |doi=10.1016/j.ejmg.2012.01.017 |url=}}</ref> Juberg-Hellman syndrome<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ogic.ca/projects/g2d_2/exam_disease.pl?U1941|title=Genes2Diseases database|author1=Carol Perez-Iratxeta |author2=Peer Bork |author3=Miguel A. Andrade }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://omim.org/entry/300088|title=Online Mendelian Inheritance in Man® An Online Catalog of Human Genes and Genetic Disorders}}</ref> epilepsy limited to females with intellectual disability (EFID)<ref name="Stevenson 2012"/> | symptoms = | complications = | onset = | duration = | types = | causes = | risks = | diagnosis = | differential = | prevention = | treatment = | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = | deaths = }}
'''Epilepsy-intellectual disability in females''' also known as '''PCDH19 gene-related epilepsy or epileptic encephalopathy, early infantile, 9''' ('''EIEE9'''), is a rare type of epilepsy that affects predominately females and is characterized by clusters of brief seizures, which start in infancy or early childhood, and is occasionally accompanied by varying degrees of cognitive impairment.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Depienne|first=C|last2=LeGeurn|first2=E|date=2012|title=PCDH19-related infantile epileptic encephalopathy: an unusual X-linked inheritance disorder|url=http://www.hal.inserm.fr/inserm-00669941/document|journal=Hum Mutat|volume=33|issue=|pages=627–634|doi=10.1002/humu.22029|pmid=|access-date=|via=}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{cite journal|title=PCDH19-related female-limited epilepsy: Further details regarding early clinical features and therapeutic efficacy|url=http://resolver.scholarsportal.info/resolve/09201211/v106i1-2/191_pfefdrecfate|journal=Epilepsy Research|volume=106|issue=1–2|pages=191–199|doi=10.1016/j.eplepsyres.2013.04.005|author1=Higurashi, N.|author2=Nakamura, M.|author3=Sugai, M.|author4=Ohfu, M.|author5=Sakauchi, M.|author6=Sugawara, Y.|author7=Nakamura, K.|author8=Kato, M.|author9=Usui, D.|author10=Mogami, Y.|author11=Fujiwara, Y.|author12=Ito, T.|author13=Ikeda, H.|author14=Imai, K.|author15=Takahashi, Y.|author16=Nukui, M.|author17=Inoue, T.|author18=Okazaki, S.|author19=Kirino, T.|author20=Tomonoh, Y.|author21=Inoue, T.|author22=Takano, K.|author23=Shimakawa, S.|author24=Hirose, S.}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://pcdh19info.org/|title=PCDH19 Alliance|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=August 22, 2016}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Specchio|first=N|last2=Marini|first2=C|last3=Terracciano|first3=A|date=2011|title=Spectrum of phenotypes in female patients with epilepsy due to protocadherin 19 mutations|url=|journal=Epilepsia|volume=52|issue=7|pages=1251–1257|doi=10.1111/j.1528-1167.2011.03063.x|pmid=21480887|access-date=|via=}}</ref> The striking pattern of onset seizures at a young age, genetic testing and laboratory results, potential developmental delays or developmental regression and associated disorders, eases diagnosis.
The National Institutes of Health Office and Rare Disease Research characterizes PCDH19 gene-related epilepsy as a rare disorder.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://rarediseases.info.nih.gov/diseases/10806/pcdh19-related-female-limited-epilepsy|title=PCDH19-related female-limited epilepsy {{!}} Genetic and Rare Diseases Information Center(GARD) – an NCATS Program|website=rarediseases.info.nih.gov|access-date=2016-08-22}}</ref> Although formal epidemiologic data is not available, results from diagnostic screenings indicate that approximately 1 out of 10 girls who have seizure onset before five years of age may have PCDH19 mutations.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Depienne|first=Christel|last2=Bouteiller|first2=Delphine|last3=Keren|first3=Boris|last4=Cheuret|first4=Emmanuel|last5=Poirier|first5=Karine|last6=Trouillard|first6=Oriane|last7=Benyahia|first7=Baya|last8=Quelin|first8=Chloé|last9=Carpentier|first9=Wassila|date=2009-02-13|title=Sporadic Infantile Epileptic Encephalopathy Caused by Mutations in PCDH19 Resembles Dravet Syndrome but Mainly Affects Females|url=http://journals.plos.org/plosgenetics/article?id=10.1371/journal.pgen.1000381|journal=PLOS Genet|volume=5|issue=2|pages=e1000381|doi=10.1371/journal.pgen.1000381|issn=1553-7404|pmc=2633044|pmid=19214208}}</ref><ref name=":6">{{cite journal | vauthors = Depienne C, Trouillard O, Bouteiller D, Gourfinkel-An I, Poirier K, Rivier F, Berquin P, Nabbout R, Chaigne D, Steschenko D, Gautier A, Hoffman-Zacharska D, Lannuzel A, Lackmy-Port-Lis M, Maurey H, Dusser A, Bru M, Gilbert-Dussardier B, Roubertie A, Kaminska A, Whalen S, Mignot C, Baulac S, Lesca G, Arzimanoglou A, LeGuern E |display-authors = 6| title = Mutations and deletions in PCDH19 account for various familial or isolated epilepsies in females | journal = Hum. Mutat. | volume = 32 | issue = 1 | pages = E1959–75 | date = January 2011 | pmid = 21053371 | pmc = 3033517 | doi = 10.1002/humu.21373 }}</ref><ref name=":17">{{Cite book|title=Neurobiology of Disease|last=Johnston|first=Michael|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2016|isbn=0199937842|location=|pages=307–309|via=}}</ref>
== Signs and symptoms == PCDH19 gene-related epilepsy is a highly variable and rare epileptic syndrome, characterized by the early-onset of seizure clusters, with a range of 4 – 60 months, and an average onset at 12.9 months.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3" /> Other aspects, such as varying degrees of cognitive impairment and behavioral and psychiatric problems, are also common, but are not essential for diagnosis of PCDH19 gene-related epilepsy.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3" /><ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Dibbens|first=LM|last2=Tarpey|first2=PS|date=June 2008|title=X-linked protocadherin 19 mutations cause female-limited epilepsy and cognitive impairment|url=|journal=Nat Genet|volume=40|issue=6|pages=776–781|doi=10.1038/ng.149|pmc=2756413}}</ref><ref name=":8">{{Cite book|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK98182/|title=Genes in infantile epileptic encephalopathies|last=Depienne|first=Christel|last2=Gourfinkel-An|first2=Isabelle|last3=Baulac|first3=Stéphanie|last4=LeGuern|first4=Eric|date=2012-01-01|publisher=National Center for Biotechnology Information (US)|editor-last=Noebels|editor-first=Jeffrey L.|edition=4th|location=Bethesda (MD)|pmid=22787626|editor-last2=Avoli|editor-first2=Massimo|editor-last3=Rogawski|editor-first3=Michael A.|editor-last4=Olsen|editor-first4=Richard W.|editor-last5=Delgado-Escueta|editor-first5=Antonio V.}}</ref><ref name="scheffer">{{cite journal|year=2008|title=Epilepsy and mental retardation limited to females: an under-recognized disorder|url=http://brain.oxfordjournals.org/content/131/4/918.full|journal=Brain|publisher=Oxford Journals|volume=131|issue=4|pages=918–927|doi=10.1093/brain/awm338|author=Scheffer, Ingrid|display-authors=etal|pmid=18234694}}</ref><ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|last=Cappelletti|first=Simona|last2=Specchio|first2=Nicola|last3=Moavero|first3=Romina|last4=Terracciano|first4=Alessandra|last5=Trivisano|first5=Marina|last6=Pontrelli|first6=Giuseppe|last7=Gentile|first7=Simonetta|last8=Vigevano|first8=Federico|last9=Cusmai|first9=Raffaella|title=Cognitive development in females with PCDH19 gene-related epilepsy|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.yebeh.2014.10.019|journal=Epilepsy & Behavior|volume=42|pages=36–40|doi=10.1016/j.yebeh.2014.10.019}}</ref><ref name=":22">{{Cite book|title=Pellock's Pediatric Epilepsy: Diagnosis and Therapy|last=Nordli, Jr.|first=Douglas|publisher=Springer Publishing Company,|year=2016|isbn=1617052434|location=|pages=386|via=}}</ref>
PCDH19 gene-related epilepsy shares several clinical features with other early-onset epileptic encephalopathies, such as [[Severe myoclonic epilepsy of infancy|Dravet Syndrome]], [[Generalized epilepsy with febrile seizures plus]] (GEFS+), [[Febrile infection-related epilepsy syndrome|FIRES]] (febrile infection–related epilepsy syndrome) [[Lennox-Gastaut syndrome]] or epilepsy of unknown origin.<ref name=":17" /> However, the disorder has a distinct evolution of symptoms, and is associated with specific genetic mutations of the PCDH19 gene.<ref name=":17" />
=== Seizures    === The hallmark characteristic of PCDH19 gene-related epilepsy is early-onset cluster seizures that often cause cyanotic spells, which start in infancy or early childhood.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3" /> The onset of the first cluster of seizures usually coincides with a fever ([[febrile seizure]]s), however subsequent seizures may be febrile or afebrile.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":10">{{cite journal | vauthors = Marini C, Mei D, Parmeggiani L, Norci V, Calado E, Ferrari A, Moreira A, Pisano T, Specchio N, Vigevano F, Battaglia D, Guerrini R | title = Protocadherin 19 mutations in girls with infantile-onset epilepsy | journal = Neurology | volume = 75 | issue = 7 | pages = 646–53 | date = August 2010 | pmid = 20713952 | doi = 10.1212/WNL.0b013e3181ed9e67 }}</ref> The seizure clusters are generally brief seizures, lasting 1–5 minutes, often accompanied by fearful screaming observed in 63% of girls.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":17" /><ref name=":9" /><ref name=":10" /><ref name=":11">{{cite journal | vauthors = Marini C, Darra F, Specchio N, Mei D, Terracciano A, Parmeggiani L, Ferrari A, Sicca F, Mastrangelo M, Spaccini L, Canopoli ML, Cesaroni E, Zamponi N, Caffi L, Ricciardelli P, Grosso S, Pisano T, Canevini MP, Granata T, Accorsi P, Battaglia D, Cusmai R, Vigevano F, Dalla Bernardina B, Guerrini R |display-authors = 6| title = Focal seizures with affective symptoms are a major feature of PCDH19 gene-related epilepsy | journal = Epilepsia | volume = 53 | issue = 12 | pages = 2111–9 | date = December 2012 | pmid = 22946748 | issn = 1528-1167| doi = 10.1111/j.1528-1167.2012.03649.x }}</ref> These cluster seizures can occur more than 10 times a day over several days, with varying amounts of time between seizure clusters.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":17" />
Over time, children with PCDH19 gene-related epilepsy tend to exhibit multiple seizure types, including [[Partial seizure|focal]], generalized [[Tonic–clonic seizure|tonic-clonic]], [[Tonic–clonic seizure|tonic]], [[Atonic seizure|atonic]], [[Myoclonic epilepsy|myclonus]], and [[absence seizure]]s.<ref name=":9" /><ref name=":22" /> In a small study of 35 female patients with PCDH19 gene-related epilepsy, rare episodes of status epilepticus occurred in about 30% of patients in the early course of the disorder.<ref name=":11" /> 
In PCDH19 gene-related epilepsy, the seizures are often refractory to treatment, especially in infancy and childhood.<ref name=":17" /><ref name=":7" /><ref name=":11" /> Additionally, seizures are usually characterized by persistence of cluster seizures, with variable frequency.<ref name=":17" /><ref name=":11" /> In a study of 35 female patients with PCDH19 gene-related epilepsy, approximately 30% had become seizure free in the girl's childhood (mean age of 12 years), yet some continued into adulthood.<ref name=":11" /> In the same study, a few patients still had recurrent cluster seizures that evolved into [[status epilepticus]] in childhood or early adolescence.<ref name=":11" />
===Developmental problems=== Beyond early-onset and treatment-resistant cluster seizures, PCDH19 gene-related epilepsy is usually, but not always, associated with cognitive and sensory impairment of varying degrees, and psychiatric and behavioral problems.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3" /><ref name=":17" /><ref name=":7" /><ref name=":8" /><ref name="scheffer" /><ref name=":9" /> It is estimated that up to 60 to 75% of the females have cognitive deficits, ranging from mild to severe intellectual disability, which do not appear to be related to frequency or severity of seizures.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3" /><ref name=":17" /><ref name=":7" /><ref name=":8" /><ref name="scheffer" /> Development over the course of a female patients’ childhood can follow one of three courses: delays from birth that persist into adulthood, normal development and then regression, or normal intellectual development.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":17" /> It is not yet clear why some people experience delayed intellectual growth and others regress with epilepsy.<ref name="scheffer" /><ref name="Marini">{{cite journal|date=June 29, 2010|title=Infantile onset focal epilepsy and epilepetic encephalopathies associated with PCDH19 gene mutations: New de novo and familial mutations.|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1528-1167.2010.02658.x/pdf|journal=9th European Congress on Epileptology|volume=51|pages=1–189|doi=10.1111/j.1528-1167.2010.02658.x|author=Marini C.|display-authors=etal}}</ref>
From the University of Melbourne study, two-thirds of PCDH19 gene-related epilepsy patients have [[borderline intellectual functioning]] or [[intellectual disability]], while one third have normal intelligence.<ref name="scheffer" /> A connection to [[Depression (mood)|depression]], [[autism]], [[Fixation (psychology)|obsessive]] and [[aggressive behavior]]s and other disorders has been observed in PCDH19 gene-related epilepsy.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3" /><ref name=":17" /><ref name=":7" /><ref name=":8" /><ref name="scheffer" /> Approximately 40-60% of girls diagnosed with a PCDH19 mutation are on the autism spectrum.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":8" /><ref name="scheffer" /><ref name=":10" />
Many of those with PCDH19 gene mutations also exhibit behavioral and psychological problems – including [[Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder|ADHD]], aggression, [[Obsessive–compulsive disorder|obsessive-compulsive disorder]], and anxiety.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":8" /><ref name="scheffer" /><ref name=":10" /> Other neurological abnormalities may present, including sleep disturbances, ictal apnea, motor deficits, [[hypotonia]], language delay, [[Sensory Integration Dysfunction|sensory integration problems]] and [[dysautonomia]].<ref name=":2" />
==Causes== A 2008 study, found a relationship between the PCDH19 gene and early onset female seizures, with subsequent studies confirming the relationship.<ref name="scheffer" /><ref name=":9" /><ref name="Marini" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Specchio|first=N|date=2011-08-01|title=Stormy Onset Epilepsy in Girls with De Novo Protocadherin 19 Mutations|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1528-1167.2011.03206.x/abstract|journal=Epilepsia|language=en|volume=52|issue=|pages=4–22|doi=10.1111/j.1528-1167.2011.03206.x|issn=1528-1167|pmid=|access-date=|via=}}</ref>
PCDH19 gene-related epilepsy can arise as a single case in a family, due to a de novo error in cell replication, or it can be inherited.<ref name=":17" /><ref name=":7" /><ref name=":8" /> In a large series of cases in which inheritance was determined, half of the PCDH19 mutations occurred de novo, and half were inherited from fathers in good health, and who had no evidence of seizures or cognitive disorders.<ref name=":17" /><ref name=":7" /><ref name=":8" />
Men and women can transmit the PCDH19 mutation, although females, but not males, usually, but not always, exhibit symptoms, which can be very mild. Females with a mutation have a 50% chance of having children who are carriers. Men have a 100% chance of transmitting the mutation to a daughter and 0% chance to a son.<ref name=":17" /><ref name=":7" /><ref name=":8" /><ref name="scheffer" />
Although males do not generally exhibit PCDH19 gene-related history such as cluster seizures, in a study involving four families with PCDH19 gene mutations, 5 of the fathers had obsessive and controlling tendencies.<ref name="scheffer" /> The linkage of chromosome Xq22.1 to PCDH19 gene-related epilepsy in females was confirmed in all of the families.<ref name="scheffer" />
The inheritance pattern is very unusual, in that men that carry the PCDH19 gene mutation on their only X-chromosome are typically unaffected, except in rare instances of somatic mosaicism.<sup>[11]</sup><ref name=":17" /> Alternatively, approximately 90% of women, who have the mutation on one of their two X-chromosomes, exhibit symptoms.<ref name=":17" /><ref name=":7" /><ref name=":8" /> It has been suggested that the greater occurrence of PCDH19-epilepsy in females may relate to [[X-inactivation|X-chromosome inactivation]], through a hypothesized mechanism termed ‘‘cellular interference’’.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":17" />
A 2011 study found instances where patients had PCDH19 mutation, but their parents did not. They found that "[[gonadal mosaicism]]” of a PCDH19 mutation in a parent is an important molecular mechanism associated with the inheritance of a mutated PCDH19 gene.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":17" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dibbens|first=L. M.|last2=Kneen|first2=R.|last3=Bayly|first3=M. A.|last4=Heron|first4=S. E.|last5=Arsov|first5=T.|last6=Damiano|first6=J. A.|last7=Desai|first7=T.|last8=Gibbs|first8=J.|last9=McKenzie|first9=F.|date=2011-04-26|title=Recurrence risk of epilepsy and mental retardation in females due to parental mosaicism of PCDH19 mutations|url=http://www.neurology.org/content/76/17/1514|journal=Neurology|language=en|volume=76|issue=17|pages=1514–1519|doi=10.1212/WNL.0b013e318217e7b6|issn=0028-3878|pmid=21519002}}</ref>
===Genetics=== The PCDH19 gene is located on the long (q) arm of the X chromosome at position 22.1.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":5" /><ref name=":7" /><ref name=":9" /> The gene encodes for protocadherin 19, a transmembrane protein of calcium-dependent cell-cell adhesion molecules that is strongly expressed in neural tissue, such as the hippocampus, cerebral cortex, thalamus, and amygdala.<ref name=":17" /><ref name=":7" /><ref name=":9" /> Protocadherin 19 appears to be related to synaptic transmission and formation of synaptic connections during brain development.<ref name=":7" /><ref name=":9" />
A mutation in the PCDH19 gene can cause the protocadherin 19 protein to be malformed, reduced in function or not produced at all.<ref name=":7" /> This abnormal expression of protocadherin 19 causes deficits in [[GABAergic]] signaling, causing the occurrence of seizures beginning in the early years of life.<ref name=":7" />
The expression of the PCDH19 mutation is highly variable, with some individuals appearing unaffected, and others showing severe disease.<ref name=":1" /> Even monozygotic twins with the mutation may have variations in seizure frequency and degree of cognitive impairment.<ref name=":1" />
Currently, the PCDH19 gene is the second most clinically relevant gene in the epilepsy field; the second largest number of epilepsy related mutations characterized thus far occur in the PCDH19 gene.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":9" /><ref name=":10" /> The [[Nav1.1|SCN1A gene]], associated with [[Severe myoclonic epilepsy of infancy|Dravet Syndrome]], is the most clinically relevant.<ref name=":12">{{Cite book|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK1318/|title=SCN1A-Related Seizure Disorders|last=Miller|first=Ian O.|last2=Sotero de Menezes|first2=Marcio A.|date=1993-01-01|publisher=University of Washington, Seattle|editor-last=Pagon|editor-first=Roberta A.|location=Seattle (WA)|pmid=20301494|editor-last2=Adam|editor-first2=Margaret P.|editor-last3=Ardinger|editor-first3=Holly H.|editor-last4=Wallace|editor-first4=Stephanie E.|editor-last5=Amemiya|editor-first5=Anne|editor-last6=Bean|editor-first6=Lora JH|editor-last7=Bird|editor-first7=Thomas D.|editor-last8=Fong|editor-first8=Chin-To|editor-last9=Mefford|editor-first9=Heather C.}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sugawara|first=Takashi|last2=Tsurubuchi|first2=Yuji|last3=Agarwala|first3=Kishan Lal|last4=Ito|first4=Masatoshi|last5=Fukuma|first5=Goryu|last6=Mazaki-Miyazaki|first6=Emi|last7=Nagafuji|first7=Hiroshi|last8=Noda|first8=Masaharu|last9=Imoto|first9=Keiji|date=2001-05-22|title=A missense mutation of the Na+ channel αII subunit gene Nav1.2 in a patient with febrile and afebrile seizures causes channel dysfunction|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/98/11/6384|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|language=en|volume=98|issue=11|pages=6384–6389|doi=10.1073/pnas.111065098|issn=0027-8424|pmc=33477|pmid=11371648}}</ref>
===Classification=== Due to its recent discovery, PCDH19 gene-related epilepsy does not have a specific classification according to the [[International League Against Epilepsy]].
PCDH19 gene-related epilepsy is thought to develop based upon a deficiency of the calcium-dependent cell-adhesion PCDH19 (protocadherin 19) gene.<ref name="PCHD19">{{cite journal |title= PCDH19 Gene |journal= Genetic Home Reference |url= http://ghr.nlm.nih.gov/gene/PCDH19 | publisher=Genetics Home Reference, U.S. National Library of Medicine |accessdate=December 30, 2011 }}</ref>{{#tag:ref|Cell adhesion is mediated by cell surface proteins.|group="nb"}} Its cause and [[pathophysiology]] (cause and mechanisms by which damage occurs) are different from other epilepsies, although the symptoms are very similar to other epileptic syndromes, such as [[Generalized epilepsy with febrile seizures plus]] (GEFS+), [[Dravet's syndrome|Dravet syndrome]] with [[SCN1A]] negative, FIRES (febrile infection–related epilepsy syndrome) [[Lennox-Gastaut syndrome]] or epilepsy of unknown origin.<ref name="firessyndrome">{{cite journal|date=November 2011|title=Acute-onset epilepsy triggered by fever mimicking FIRES febrile infection–related epilepsy syndrome: The role of protocadherin 19 (PCDH19) gene mutation|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1528-1167.2011.03193.x/abstract|journal=Epilepsia|volume=52|issue=11|pages=e172–e175|doi=10.1111/j.1528-1167.2011.03193.x|author1=Nicola Specchio|author2=Lucia Fusco|author3=Federico Vigevano|pmid=21777234}}</ref>
==Diagnosis== PCDH19 gene-related epilepsy is clinically based on patient and family seizure history, cognitive and behavioral neuropsychological evaluation, neurological examination, [[Electroencephalography|electroencephalogram (EEG)]] studies, and long term observation. Diagnosis is confirmed using molecular testing for PCDH19 mutations.<ref name=":10" /><ref name=":12" />
===Diagnostic test=== The test is particularly indicated in children who have had cluster seizures in series. It is also recommended for patients who are diagnosed GEFS+ and when the seizures are associated with fever, infection, experienced regression, delayed cognitive growth or behavioral problems. The test is typically ordered by [[neurologist]]s. The diagnostic test can be done by drawing blood or saliva of the patient and their immediate family. It is analyzed in laboratories that specialize in [[genetic testing]]. Genetic testing can aid in a firmer diagnosis and understanding of the disorder, may aid in identifying the optimal treatment plan and if positive, testing of the parents can determine if they are carriers. (See [[Genetic Counseling]])
==Treatment==
===Medication=== [[Antiepileptic drugs]] (AEDs) are used in most cases to control seizures, however, PCDH19 gene-related epilepsy is generally associated with early-onset development of drug resistant seizures.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":17" /><ref name=":22" /> Existing data supports the use of “rational polypharmacy,” which consists of a step-wise addition of AEDs until a patient responds favorably or experiences intolerable adverse events.<ref name=":5" /> In general, as in other types of uncontrolled epilepsy, the use of drugs with different mechanisms of action appears to be more effective than combining drugs with similar mechanisms of action.<ref name=":5" />
No currently marketed AEDs have been extensively studied in PCDH19 gene-related epilepsy and there is no established treatment strategy for girls diagnosed with PCDH19 gene-related epilepsy.<ref name=":22" /><ref name=":12" /> Patients may respond well to treatment with [[levetiracetam]] and in cases of drug resistance, [[stiripentol]], which is not approved in the U.S. but is available through the FDA Expanded Access IND process.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":12" />
===Urgent care=== At the hospital, physicians follow standard protocol for managing seizures. Cluster seizures are generally controlled by [[benzodiazepines]] such as [[diazepam]], [[midazolam]], [[lorazepam]] or [[clonazepam]]. The use of [[Oxygen therapy|oxygen]] is recommended in the United States, but in Europe it is only recommended in cases of prolonged epileptic status.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ninds.nih.gov/disorders/epilepsy/detail_epilepsy.htm|title=The Epilepsies and Seizures: Hope Through Research|website=www.ninds.nih.gov|access-date=2016-08-22}}</ref>
==Epidemiology== The National Institute of Health Office and Rare Disease Research characterizes PCDH19 gene-related epilepsy as a rare disorder.<ref name=":4" /> Rare diseases, by definition, are diseases that affect fewer than 200,000 people in the United States. Since the mutation associated with PCDH19 gene-related epilepsy was only recently identified in 2008, the true incidence of the disease is generally unknown.<ref name=":7" />
Although formal epidemiologic data is not available, results from diagnostic screening indicates that approximately 1 out of 10 girls who have seizure onset before five years of age may have PCDH19 gene mutations.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":6" /><ref name=":17" /> Additionally, PCDH19 screening of several large cohorts of females with early onset febrile-related epilepsy has resulted in a rate of approximately 10% of mutation-positive individuals.<ref name=":17" /><ref name=":10" /><ref name=":12" />
==History==
Juberg and Hellman originally described the disorder in 1971 in the ''[[Journal of Pediatrics]]'', where they reported a family in which 15 female relatives, who were related either as sisters or first cousins through their fathers, had early onset seizures with cognitive impairments.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":4" /><ref name=":22" /> In subsequent peer-reviewed literature, the disorder was referred to as “epilepsy and mental retardation limited to female” (EFMR), and later called EIEE9 or Juberg-Hellman Syndrome.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":4" /><ref name=":7" /> The [[syndrome]] in this family was characterized by the occurrence of childhood seizures. Some of the girls showed developmental regression with intellectual disabilities that ranged from mild to profound. The disorder has an unusual inheritance pattern. It is considered [[X-linked]] dominant with male carriers. Women and men with the affected gene can transmit the disease. The men expressed a normal [[phenotype]]. The disorder was shown to be linked to [[mutation]]s via Xq22 [[microsatellite]] markers.[[Epilepsy-intellectual disability in females#cite note-23|<sup>[nb 4]</sup>]][[Epilepsy-intellectual disability in females#cite note-scheffer-4|<sup>[4]</sup>]]
Due to the apparent female-limited expression of the condition, it eluded genetic mapping until 1997, which is when Ryan et al. mapped the responsible gene to the X-chromosome.<ref name=":13">{{Cite journal|last=Tan|first=Chuan|last2=Shard|first2=Chloe|last3=Ranieri|first3=Enzo|last4=Hynes|first4=Kim|last5=Pham|first5=Duyen H.|last6=Leach|first6=Damian|last7=Buchanan|first7=Grant|last8=Corbett|first8=Mark|last9=Shoubridge|first9=Cheryl|date=2015-09-15|title=Mutations of protocadherin 19 in female epilepsy (PCDH19-FE) lead to allopregnanolone deficiency|url=http://hmg.oxfordjournals.org/content/24/18/5250|journal=Human Molecular Genetics|language=en|volume=24|issue=18|pages=5250–5259|doi=10.1093/hmg/ddv245|issn=0964-6906|pmid=26123493}}</ref>
Eleven years after the success of Ryan et al., in 2008, systematic sequencing of X-chromosome exons in seven large families diagnosed with EFMR revealed PCDH19 gene mutations as the cause. This led to a shift in describing EMFR as PCDH19 gene-related epilepsy.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":8" /><ref name="scheffer" /><ref name=":10" /><ref name=":13" /> The discovery of the PCDH19 gene mutation led to the development of a genetic test for PCDH19 gene-related epilepsy.
In 2009, Depienne et al. identified a male with a [[Mosaic (genetics)|somatic mosaicism]] for PCDH19 gene deletion and a Dravet-like seizure disorder.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":17" /><ref name=":13" /><ref name=":23">{{Cite journal|last=Terracciano|first=Alessandra|last2=Trivisano|first2=Marina|last3=Cusmai|first3=Raffaella|last4=De Palma|first4=Luca|last5=Fusco|first5=Lucia|last6=Compagnucci|first6=Claudia|last7=Bertini|first7=Enrico|last8=Vigevano|first8=Federico|last9=Specchio|first9=Nicola|date=2016-03-01|title=PCDH19-related epilepsy in two mosaic male patients|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/epi.13295/abstract|journal=Epilepsia|language=en|volume=57|issue=3|pages=e51–e55|doi=10.1111/epi.13295|issn=1528-1167|pmid=26765483}}</ref><ref name=":24">{{Cite journal|last=Thiffault|first=Isabelle|last2=Farrow|first2=Emily|last3=Smith|first3=Laurie|last4=Lowry|first4=Jennifer|last5=Zellmer|first5=Lee|last6=Black|first6=Benjamin|last7=Abdelmoity|first7=Ahmed|last8=Miller|first8=Neil|last9=Soden|first9=Sarah|date=2016-06-01|title=PCDH19-related epileptic encephalopathy in a male mosaic for a truncating variant|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/ajmg.a.37617/abstract|journal=American Journal of Medical Genetics Part A|language=en|volume=170|issue=6|pages=1585–1589|doi=10.1002/ajmg.a.37617|issn=1552-4833|pmid=27016041}}</ref> The findings resulted in Depienne et al. to identify PCDH19 mutations in patients with SCN1A negative Dravet syndrome.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":17" /><ref name=":13" /> This led to additional reports of PCDH19 positive patients, which broadened the clinical spectrum of the disorder.<ref name=":13" /><ref name=":23" /><ref name=":24" />
== Society and culture== Caregivers of individuals living with PCDH19 gene-related epilepsy may seek support and information from a variety of resources, including the PCDH19 Alliance, The Cute Syndrome Foundation, and Insieme per la Ricerca PCDH19 - ONLUS (Italy).
The PCDH19 World Conference, which is organized by Insieme per la Ricerca PCDH19 - ONLUS, occurs every other year, in odd years, in Rome, Italy. In alternating years, the PCDH19 Epilepsy Professional and Family Symposium is hosted in San Francisco, California.
In 2014, the PCDH19 Registry was established, which is organized and funded by the PCHD19 Alliance, Boston Children’s Hospital and the University of California, San Francisco.<ref name=":2" />
International PCDH19 Awareness Day is held annually on November 9.
==Research==
=== Registry === A PCDH19 Registry was established by the PCDH19 Alliance, [[Boston Children's Hospital|Boston Children’s Hospital]] and the [[University of California, San Francisco]], to provide a meaningful resource of patients with PCDH19 gene-related epilepsy and to better understand the epilepsy and behavioral aspects associated with the mutation.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":14">{{Cite web|url=http://www.childrenshospital.org/centers-and-services/epilepsy-genetics-program/research-and-innovation|title=Epilepsy Genetics Program {{!}} Research and Innovation {{!}} Boston Children's Hospital|last=2013|first=Boston Childrens Hospital|website=www.childrenshospital.org|access-date=2016-08-22}}</ref>
Parallel associations European families are sponsoring basic and applied research in an Australian team and researching in other projects with the aim of finding a drug target for epilepsy PCDH19.<sup>[28]</sup>
=== Basic research === Ann Poduri and Alex Rotenberg at Boston Children’s Hospital are currently conducting PCDH19-related epilepsy in zebrafish.<ref name=":14" /><ref name=":15">{{Cite web|url=http://www.thecutesyndrome.com/research.html|title=PCDH19 and SCN8A Research Funded By The Cute Syndrome|website=The Cute Syndrome Foundation: Funding PCDH19 Epilepsy &<br />SCN8A Epilepsy Research|access-date=2016-08-22}}</ref> The research, which is funded by grants from The Cute Syndrome Foundation and The Richard A. and Susan F. Smith President’s Innovation Fund of Boston Children’s Hospital, hopes to establish an animal model of PCDH19 gene-related epilepsy, which can then be used to screen potential therapeutics and treatments.<ref name=":14" /><ref name=":15" />
Dr. Jack Parent and his research team at the [[University of Michigan]] are currently conducting research to understand how PCHD19 gene mutations leads to disruptions in brain development.<ref name=":16">{{Cite web|url=http://pcdh19info.org/research/|title=RESEARCH - PCDH19 Alliance|website=PCDH19 Alliance|language=en-US|access-date=2016-08-22}}</ref><ref name=":18">{{Cite web|url=http://www.thecutesyndrome.com/news.html|title=News about PCDH19 Epilepsy and SCN8A Epilepsy and The Cute Syndrome Foundation|website=The Cute Syndrome Foundation: Funding PCDH19 Epilepsy &<br />SCN8A Epilepsy Research|access-date=2016-08-22}}</ref> The research, funded by a grant from The Cute Syndrome Foundation, is seeking to reprogram [[fibroblast]]s from subjects with the PCHD19 mutation into [[induced pluripotent stem cell]]s (iPSC), which will then be used to make patient-specific neurons in a cell culture environment.<ref name=":16" /><ref name=":18"/> The researchers are looking to see if these patient-specific neurons produce epileptic-like activity, as well as to discover the mechanism underlying the seizures and cognitive dysfunction associated with PCDH19 mutations.<ref name=":16" /><ref name=":18"/>
The Cute Syndrome Foundation and Insieme per la Ricerca PCDH19 - ONLUS recently awarded a two-year research grant to Drs. Maria Passafaro and Elena Battaglioli, from the CNR Neuroscience Institute and [[University of Milan]]o, respectively.<ref name=":18"/><ref name=":19">{{Cite web|url=http://www.pcdh19research.org/ENG/news_iniziative_ENG.html|title=Insieme per la Ricerca PCDH19 – ONLUS|last=|first=|date=|website=www.pcdh19research.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2016-08-22}}</ref> The researchers plan to unravel the molecular mechanism of PCDH19 gene mutations.<ref name=":18" /><ref name=":19" /> The proposal also includes using AON exon skipping, which would be the first use of this method in epilepsy.<ref name=":18" /><ref name=":19" />
Parallel associations European families are sponsoring basic and applied research in an Australian team and researching in other projects with the aim of finding a drug target for epilepsy PCDH19.<ref name="researchau">PCDH19 Association "Insieme per la Ricerca PCDH19"</ref>{{clarify|date=December 2011}}
=== Gene therapy === It was assumed that all encephalopathies or cognitive impairments were irreversible, but an experiment with mice showed that is not always the case.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Guy|first=Jacky|last2=Gan|first2=Jian|last3=Selfridge|first3=Jim|last4=Cobb|first4=Stuart|last5=Bird|first5=Adrian|date=2007-02-23|title=Reversal of Neurological Defects in a Mouse Model of Rett Syndrome|url=http://science.sciencemag.org/content/315/5815/1143|journal=Science|language=en|volume=315|issue=5815|pages=1143–1147|doi=10.1126/science.1138389|issn=0036-8075|pmid=17289941}}</ref> In that experiment, MECP2 protein was blocked; males died, and females developed Rett syndrome (seizures, cognitive and psychomotor problems, respiratory problems, etc.) When the researchers reversed the situation and let the MECP2 protein work properly, the mice recovered.<sup>[''[[Wikipedia:Please clarify|clarification needed]]'']</sup> This research revolutionized understanding regarding genetic syndromes that present with neurological impairment or intellectual disabilities.
=== Therapeutics === In February 2015, Marinus Pharmaceuticals commenced a Phase 2 proof-of-concept clinical trial to evaluate the safety and efficacy of [[ganaxolone]], a synthetic analog of the [[Neuroactive steroid|neurosteroid]] [[allopregnanolone]], for the treatment of uncontrolled seizure in pediatric females with PCDH19 gene-related epilepsy.<ref name=":20">{{Cite web|url=http://ir.marinuspharma.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=894284|title=Marinus Pharmaceuticals Initiates Clinical Trial With Ganaxolone in PCDH19 Female Pediatric Epilepsy (NASDAQ:MRNS)|website=ir.marinuspharma.com|access-date=2016-08-22}}</ref><ref name=":21">{{Cite web|url=https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT02358538?term=NCT02358538&rank=1|title=A Multicenter, Open-Label Proof-of-Concept Trial of Ganaxolone in Children With PCDH19 Female Pediatric Epilepsy - Full Text View - ClinicalTrials.gov|website=clinicaltrials.gov|access-date=2016-08-22}}</ref> The study will enroll up to 10 female pediatric patients, between the ages of 2 and 10 years old, with a confirmed PCDH19 genetic mutation.<ref name=":16" /><ref name=":18"/><ref name=":21" /> The primary endpoint of the study is percent change in seizure frequency per 28 days relative to baseline.<ref name=":20" /><ref name=":21" />
The Epilepsies Research Centre and Department of Medicine, University of Melbourne, are working on a compound to treat this disease. On May 26, 2011 it patented a method of diagnosis and PCDH19 gene-related epilepsy treatment.<ref>{{cite patent|country=US|number=US 2011/0126302 A1|status=pending|title=[http://www.google.es/patents/about?id=foDmAQAAEBAJ&dq=efmr Diagnostic and Therapeutic Methods for EFMR (Epilepsy and Mental Retardation]|pubdate=May 26, 2011|gdate=|fdate=January 5, 2009|pridate=|inventor=Dibbens, L.M.; Scheffer, I.; Berkovic, S.F.; Mulley, J.C.; Geez, J|invent1=|invent2=|assign1=|assign2=|class=}}</ref>
==Notes== {{Reflist|group=nb}}

revision.text:
'''Feminist health centers''' are independent, not-for-profit, alternative medical facilities that primarily provide [[gynecology|gynecological]] health care. Many [[feminism|feminist]] health centers were founded in the 1970s as part of the [[Women_in_medicine#Women.27s_health_movement_in_the_1970s|women's health movement]] in the United States. These centers were founded with the purposes of challenging the [[medicalization]] of health care, providing an alternative to mainstream health facilities, and increasing access to gynecological information and services for all women, regardless of race, class, sexual orientation, or insurance coverage.
==History== Feminist health centers emerged as a part of the women’s health movement in the 1970s. The women’s health movement grew out of social movements of the 1960s, including the [[New Left]], the [[Civil Rights Movement]], and dissatisfaction with the delivery of women’s health care. Members of the women’s health movement saw health care as a highly politicized issue and wanted to challenge the [[racism]], [[class discrimination|classism]], and [[sexism]] they saw in professionalized medicine.
In her history of the women’s health movement, feminist anthropologist [[Sandra Morgen]] notes, “Feminist clinics never accounted for the majority of women’s health movement groups. But […] they were vanguard organizations that were fertile soils for many of the movement’s innovations.”<ref>Morgen, 71.</ref> Feminist health centers were intended as a challenge to the way mainstream health care was delivered. Many in the women's health movement embraced [[self-help]], from reading the seminal text ''[[Our Bodies, Ourselves]]'' to performing illegal abortions as part of the infamous [[Jane Collective]] in Chicago.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://womensenews.org/story/health/040504/our-bodies-ourselves-turns-35-today |title= Our Bodies, Ourselves Turns 35 Today |author= Molly M. Ginty |date= May 4, 2004 |publisher= Women's eNews |accessdate=May 6, 2012}} </ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fwhc.org/jane.htm |title= Jane: An Abortion Service |date= January 1998 |publisher= Feminist Women's Health Center DBA Cedar River Clinics |accessdate=May 6, 2012}}</ref><ref>Morgen, 18-30.</ref> The philosophy of self-help was practiced in feminist health centers by the teaching of cervical self-exam, and also by creating a more collaborative relationship between the health care provider (who was not necessarily a physician) and patient.<ref>{{cite web |last1= N.Y. Times News Service |date=November 18, 1979 |title=Feminist health center under fire |pages=5-D |publisher= Wilmington Star-News |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=s9ZQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ORMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3641,3944318&dq=feminist+health+centers&hl=en |accessdate= May 8, 2012 }}</ref> The Federation of Feminist Women's Health Centers, an organized, nationwide group of feminist health centers, published self-help books such as "How To Stay Out of the Gynecologist's Office." These books went further than expanding women's knowledge about their own bodies by additionally enabling women to treat some common infections, such as UTIs and yeast infections, with home remedies.<ref>{{cite web |last1=McCormack |first1=Patricia |date= January 26, 1982 |title= Feminists Authors Offer Self-Help Health Books |pages=14 |publisher=Schenectady Gazette |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=cmxGAAAAIBAJ&sjid=f-kMAAAAIBAJ&pg=1196,2515596&dq=feminist+health+centers&hl=en |accessdate= May 5, 2012}}</ref> Health activists decried the “doctor knows best” model of care, noting that the [[professionalization]] of medical care had excluded women as both providers and consumers of medical care.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.feministcenter.org/about-fwhc/mission-history-values |title= History, Mission, and Values |publisher= Feminist Women's Health Center of Atlanta, GA |accessdate=May 6, 2012}}</ref><ref>Ginty.</ref><ref>See Kline and Morgen.</ref>
The body of scholarship that emerged from the women’s health movement underscores the fact that, historically, women had been health care providers for millennia.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.healthguidance.org/entry/6355/1/Medical-History--Women-in-Medicine.html |title= Medical History -- Women in Medicine |author= Albert S. Lyons |publisher= Health Guidance |accessdate=May 6, 2012}}</ref> It was not until the mid-nineteenth century that women were pushed out of medicine by increasingly professionalized health care delivery in the United States. Women were further excluded from medicine through the doctor-patient relationship, by which women were presented with minimal information or choices about the health care they received, and even their own bodies. Feminist health activists argued that the drape used by gynecologists during [[pelvic exam]]s symbolized a veil of secrecy.<ref>Morgen, 124.</ref>
Throughout their early years, feminist health centers struggled to uphold their ideals while simultaneously meeting the needs of their clients and their employees. Feminist scholars [[Myra Marx Ferree]] and Patricia Yancey Martin argue, “Feminist organizations are an amalgam, a blend of institutionalized and social movement practices. […] A movement organization is not a contradiction in terms, but it is, by definition, in tension. It is always a compromise between the ideals by which it judges itself and the realities of its daily practices.” <ref>Ferree and Martin, 7-8.</ref> Many clinics realized that change was necessary for their continued operations – for example, many feminist health centers began as [[collective]]s. While many activists believed that collective decision-making promoted [[egalitarianism]], most clinics found that reaching a consensus took too much time, especially as organizations grew to include more personnel and began to serve more clients.<ref>Morgen, 110.</ref>
While most clinics found ways to resolve, or at least maintain, the tension between ideals and practice, some refused to compromise. The Women’s Community Health Center in Cambridge, Massachusetts is an example of a clinic that maintained an unyielding commitment to its political values. The women who ran the center were unwilling to rely on outside funding, feeling that outside support could coopt their mission.<ref>Morgen, 97.</ref> Unfortunately, their refusal to seek external financial support led to a short shelf life for the clinic – the Women’s Community Health Center was only open from 1974 until 1981, and was plagued by financial troubles and internal disputes throughout its existence.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://oasis.lib.harvard.edu/oasis/deliver/~sch00351 |title= Women's Community Health Center (Cambridge, Mass.) Records, 1953-1987 (inclusive), 1973-1981 (bulk): A Finding Aid |author= Paula K. Aloisio |date= March 2005 |publisher=Women's Community Health Center |accessdate=May 6, 2012}}</ref>
In addition to facing internal conflicts, many feminist health centers faced external opposition to their existence. The desire of feminist health activists to alter the delivery of health services alienated many physicians, who saw feminist health centers as offering both criticism and competition to their mainstream practices. Most feminist health centers did cooperate with the medical establishment somewhat, due in large part to state laws requiring physicians to be a part of clinic staff or to perform abortions.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.guttmacher.org/statecenter/spibs/spib_OAL.pdf |title=State Policies in Brief: An Overview of Abortion Laws |date=May 1, 2012 |publisher=Guttmacher Institute |accessdate=May 6, 2012}}</ref> Although many feminist health centers initially sought female doctors to join their ranks, the exclusion of women from medical schools meant that most feminist health centers had male physicians on staff.<ref>Morgen, 92.</ref> However, not all clinics had a cooperative relationship with medical professionals. The Tallahassee Feminist Women's Health Center had to recruit out-of-town doctors to perform abortions at their clinic because the center's founder had given a newspaper interview criticizing the local medical community, thereby causing their staff physicians to quit and antagonizing other area doctors.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=s9ZQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ORMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3641,3944318&dq=feminist+health+centers&hl=en |title= Feminist health center under fire}}</ref>
Feminist health centers also faced (and continue to face) frequent attacks, criticism, and protests, primarily relating to their role as abortion providers. Many clinics have been attacked by arsonists and subject to bombings, with some clinics undergoing multiple attacks.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Hu0vAAAAIBAJ&sjid=tO4DAAAAIBAJ&pg=5055,1378481&dq=feminist+health+centers&hl=en |title= Suspicious fire damages feminist health center |author= Associated Press |date= December 4, 1983|page= D2 |publisher= The Spokesman-Review |accessdate=May 6, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=S9ZGAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ovMMAAAAIBAJ&pg=3056,10662&dq=feminist+health+centers&hl=en |title= Women's clinic reopens despite fire |author=Associated Press |date= June 1, 2000 |page=A3 |publisher= Lewiston Sun Journal |accessdate=May 6, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=4GAPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=soYDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6626,222471&dq=feminist+health+centers&hl=en |title= Abortion mail bombs discovered |author=United Press International |date= December 4, 1985|page= A-3|publisher= The Oregon Bulletin |accessdate=May 6, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= |title=Abortion clinic fire called arson |author= Associated Press |date=Associated Press |page=3 |publisher= The Telegraph|accessdate=May 8, 2012}}</ref> Clinic workers and patients also faced harassment from anti-abortion protestors. During the 1980s, the anti-abortion group [[History of Operation Rescue|Operation Rescue]] was often a fixation outside of many clinics. In 1988, during the Democratic National Convention held in Atlanta, the [[Feminist Women's Health Center (Atlanta, GA)|Feminist Women's Health Center]] was bombarded with hundreds of protestors outside its doors, making it difficult to continue clinic operations.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=u_wlAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_PMFAAAAIBAJ&pg=924,1574545&dq=feminist+health+centers&hl=en |title= Abortion clinics struggle to operate as 'siege' continues |author= Associated Press |date= October 6, 1988 |page=3 |publisher= Miami Herald |accessdate=May 6, 2012}}</ref> The Operation Rescue protests in Atlanta resulted in hundreds of arrests.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/08/11/us/falwell-supports-protesters-at-anti-abortion-rally-in-atlanta.html |title= Falwell Supports Protestors At Anti-Abortion Rally in Atlanta |author= Alan S. Weiner |date= August 11, 1988 |publisher= The New York Times |accessdate=May 6, 2012}}</ref>
==Differences from mainstream health clinics==
Although most feminist health centers are abortion providers, not all of them are. For example, the Chicago Women’s Health Center has remained committed to the principles of self-help and informed consent, and strives to provide care to underserved populations, but does not provide abortion care.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chicagowomenshealthcenter.org/about-page/womens-health-movement |title=Women's Health Movement |publisher= Chicago Women's Health Center |accessdate=May 6, 2012}} </ref> Conversely, not all abortion providers are feminist health centers – in fact, most are not, just as most providers of women’s health care are not feminist.
The women’s health movement has succeeded in changing mainstream health care in several ways, including mandating the practice of informed consent and implementing the discussion of multiple treatment options.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.womenshealthspecialists.org/about-us/womens-health-movement |title= Women's Health Movement |author= Cindy Pearson |publisher= Women's Health Specialists |accessdate=May 6, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.rhrealitycheck.org/blog/2007/01/02/life-support-for-feminist-health-care |title=Life Support for Feminist Health Care? |author= Amie Newman |date= January 2, 2007 |publisher= RH Reality Check |accessdate=May 6, 2012}}</ref> Thus, some practices that were once deemed radical and found primarily in feminist health centers have become routine in medical facilities throughout the country. However, feminist health centers remain distinct from their mainstream counterparts in important ways.
Feminist health centers continue to see health care as a political issue – they believe that improvements in women’s health come not only from advances in medicine, but also from society making inroads against injustice and inequality.<ref>Morgen, 237.</ref> Feminist health centers will not shy away from controversial topics, including abortion, which most centers are committed to providing as a critical component of comprehensive women’s health care.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.rhrealitycheck.org/blog/2009/12/21/interview-feminist-abortion-network |title= An Interview With the Feminist Abortion Network |author= Amie Newman |date=December 21, 2009 |publisher=RH Reality Check |accessdate=May 6, 2012}}</ref><ref>Morgen, 150.</ref>
Furthermore, feminist health centers maintain a commitment to reaching underserved populations that is largely unseen in other medical providers. Feminist health centers provide services to minorities, immigrants, refugees, the LGBTQI community, and the uninsured.<ref>Morgen, 151.</ref> To meet these needs, clinics usually offer sliding scale or reduced fees for services, and offer free health care to those who cannot afford to pay. In addition to reaching these oft-neglected populations, feminist health centers try to provide sensitive and respectful health care, recognizing health disparities in underserved groups and tailoring their services to the needs of the communities in which they operate.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.concordmonitor.com/article/282627/feminist-health-center-fills-key-role?SESSf6487623b7d29dbfe3ab1dd2e7e7712f=google|title= Feminist Health Center fills a key role |author= Dalia Vidunas |date= September 28, 2011 |publisher=Concord Monitor |accessdate=May 6, 2012}} </ref>
==Feminist Health Centers==
Listed in alphabetical order: * [http://www.bluemountainclinic.org/ Blue Mountain Clinic] in Missoula, Montana * [http://www.cedarriverclinics.org/ Cedar River Clinics] in Renton and Tacoma, Washington * [http://www.chicagowomenshealthcenter.org/ Chicago Women's Health Center] in Chicago, Illinois * [http://feministhealth.org/ Concord Feminist Health Center] in Concord, New Hampshire * [http://www.emmagoldman.com/ Emma Goldman Clinic] in Iowa City, Iowa * [[Feminist Women's Health Center (Atlanta, GA)|Feminist Women’s Health Center]] in Atlanta, GA * [http://joangloveringhealthcenter.org/choice/?doing_wp_cron Joan G. Lovering Health Center] in Portsmouth, New Hampshire * [http://www.mabelwadsworth.org/ Mabel Wadsworth Women’s Health Center] in Bangor, Maine * [[Choices: Memphis Center for Reproductive Health]] in Memphis, Tennessee * [http://www.preterm.org/ Preterm] in Cleveland, Ohio * [http://wholewomanshealth.com/ Whole Women's Health] multiple clinics in the U.S. * [http://www.boulderwomenshealth.org/ Women’s Health - Boulder Valley Women's Health Center] in Boulder, Colorado * [http://www.whcwva.com/ Women’s Health Center of West Virginia] in Charleston, West Virginia * [http://www.womenshealthcenterduluth.org/ Women’s Health Center] in Duluth, Minnesota * [http://www.womenshealthspecialists.org/ Women’s Health Specialists of California] in Sacramento, Chico, Redding, and Grass Valley, California
==References== {{Reflist|33em}}
==Bibliography== *{{cite book |title= Feminist Organizations: Harvest of the New Women's Movement |last= Ferree|first= Myra Marx |authorlink= |author2=Patricia Yancey Martin |year= 1995 |publisher= Temple University Press |location= Philadelphia |isbn= 978-1566392297 }} *{{cite book |title=Bodies of Knowledge: Sexuality, Reproduction, and Women's Health in the Second Wave |last= Kline |first= Wendy |year= 2010 |publisher= University of Chicago |location= Chicago |isbn= 978-0226443089}} *{{cite book |title=Into Our Own Hands: The Women's Health Movement in the United States, 1969-1990. |last= Morgen |first=Sandra |year=2002 |publisher=Rutgers University Press |location=New Brunswick, NJ |isbn= 978-0813530710}}
[[Category:Women's health]] [[Category:Feminism and health]]

The '''Forensic Network''' (the shortened name of the '''Forensic Mental Health Services Managed Care Network''') is one of Scotland's Managed Clinical Networks.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://google.com/search?q=cache:97GDSqtpw7QJ:www.healthmanagementonline.co.uk/pdf.pl%3Ffile%3Dmanbrief/Managed%2520Clinical%2520Networks%2520(July%25202005).pdf+journal+scotland+forensic+mental+health+network&hl=en&ct=clnk&cd=16&gl=us |title=Managed Clinical Networks in Scotland |pages=2 |publisher=Health Management Library |accessdate=2008-02-29}}</ref> The Network was established in [[Scotland]] in September 2003 by the Scottish Government, in conjunction with "The Mental Health (Care and Treatment) (Scotland) Act 2003",<ref>{{Cite journal |url=http://pb.rcpsych.org/cgi/content/full/30/11/423 |last=Thomson |first=L.D.G. |title=The Mental Health (Care and Treatment) (Scotland) Act 2003: legislation for mentally disordered offenders |publisher=British Journal of Psychiatry |location=London |journal=Psychiatric Bulletin |volume=30 |pages=423–429 |year=2006 |oclc=109552914 |doi=10.1192/pb.30.11.423 |accessdate=2008-02-29 |issue=11 |postscript=<!--None-->}}</ref> and following a review of the State Hospital's Board for Scotland, 'The Right Place - The Right Time'.<ref>[http://www.forensicnetwork.scot.nhs.uk/documents/The%20Right%20Place%20The%20Right%20Time.pdf Scottish Executive Health Department, 2002]</ref>
The review stated that a Forensic Mental Health Services Network Managed Care Network should be established to address fragmentation across the Forensic Mental Health Estate, to overview the processes for determining the most effective care for mentally disordered offenders, consider wider issues surrounding patient pathways, and align strategic planning across Scotland.<ref>[http://www.forensicnetwork.scot.nhs.uk/documents/ian_gordon.pdf Gordon, 2003 - The Response to Consultation Paper]</ref><ref>[http://www.parliament.scot/parliamentarybusiness/report.aspx?r=4438&mode=pdf Scottish Parliament, 2003]</ref>
== Activities == Under the auspices of the [[Scottish National Health Service]], the Network is multi-agency, multi-disciplinary and multi-regional, linked with [[Scottish Prison Service]], Social Work Services, and [[Police]], [[Criminal Justice]] agencies, the Scottish Government and [[Carers]], amongst others. The [[Scottish Government|Scottish Ministers]] invited Andreana Adamson, Chief Executive of the State Hospital, to lead on its development: :"The therapeutic aim of inpatient forensic services is to address violent, aggressive and offending behaviour. It is vital that patients are treated in accommodation appropriate to their needs in an environment that supports their rehabilitation."(Adamson, 2008)<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.theherald.co.uk/news/focus/display.var.2060780.0.Carstairs_changing_a_mindset.php |last=Adams |first=Lucy |title=Carstairs: changing a mindset |date=2008-02-21 |publisher=The Herald Focus |accessdate=2008-02-29}}</ref>
The aim for the Network is to bring a pan-dimensional SCOTLAND approach to the planning, development and rehabilitation pathways for forensic mental health services. The Network host several professional groups, commission short life working groups to tackle specific concerns, and facilitate clinical forums on a variety of key topic areas. The Network take a regional approach in order to achieve their aims of addressing fragmentation across forensic mental health services and representatives from NHS regions sit on an advisory committee and board to provide guidance and input into national approaches. [http://www.forensicnetwork.scot.nhs.uk/forensic-network/ Information on the regional structure and the current work of the Forensic Network can be found on their website] and in their [http://www.forensicnetwork.scot.nhs.uk/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/Annual-Report-2016-Public-Final-Draft.pdf annual report]. [http://www.forensicnetwork.scot.nhs.uk/school-of-forensic-mental-health/clinical-fora-training-events/ Information on Upcoming Events can be found here].
The Forensic Network host the [http://www.forensicnetwork.scot.nhs.uk/school-of-forensic-mental-health/ School of Forensic Mental Health (SoFMH)] which was established in 2007 and provides colleagues across the Forensic Network with teaching, training and research support. It is a virtual school and has connections with many secondary education providers, providing short professional courses, academic courses and distance learning courses across Scotland. Its flagship programme suite is the New to Forensic courses which have received international interest and commendation. More on the work of the school and [http://www.forensicnetwork.scot.nhs.uk/school-of-forensic-mental-health/clinical-fora-training-events/ upcoming events] can be found on the Forensic Network website.

[[Category:NHS Scotland]] [[Category:Crime in Scotland]] [[Category:Mental health organisations in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Mental health in Scotland]] [[Category:Mental health law in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Forensics organizations]] [[Category:Organizations established in 2003]]

{{Multiple issues| {{More citations needed|date=July 2007}} {{cleanup rewrite|date=October 2014}} }} [[File:Phasianus colchicus 2 tom (Lukasz Lukasik).jpg|Right|thumb|[[Common pheasant]], widely introduced and hunted as game]] '''Game''' or '''quarry''' is any [[animal]] [[hunting|hunted]] for [[trophy hunting|sport]] or for [[meat|food]], and the meat of those animals. The type and range of animals hunted for food varies in different parts of the world. {{TOC limit|3}}
== Description == Game or quarry is any [[animal]] [[hunting|hunted]] for its [[meat]] or for [[trophy hunting|sport]].
The term ''game'' arises in [[medieval hunting]] terminology by the late 13th century and is particular to English, the word derived from the generic Old English ''gamen'' (Germanic ''[[:wikt:Appendix:Proto-Germanic/gamaną|*gamanan]]'') "joy, amusement, sport, merriment".
''Quarry'' in the generic meaning is early modern (first recorded 1610), in the more specific sense "bird targeted in falconry" late 14th and 15th centuries as ''quirre'' "entrails of deer placed on the hide and given to the hunting-dogs as a reward", from [[Old French]] ''cuiriee'' "spoil, quarry" (ultimately Latin ''[[:wikt:corium|corium]]'' "hide"), but influenced by ''corée'' "viscera, entrails" (Late Latin ''[[:wikt:corata|*corata]]'' "entrails", from ''cor'' "heart").
Unlike many commercial meat products, the meat from wild animals (especially herbivores), when prepared correctly, is very healthy and nutrient-dense. This is primarily due to the animal's natural diet and healthy lifestyle. It can be virtually assured that the animal was never bred or raised in unsanitary conditions, fed a diet of grain, confined to a cage, or injected with any artificial hormones. On the other hand, the act of killing the animal for its meat is more apparent and can only be done within reasonable regulations to ensure continuity of the animal species and its meat resource.
Small game includes small animals, such as [[rabbit]]s, [[pheasant]]s, [[geese]] or [[duck]]s. Large game includes animals like [[deer]], [[moose]], and [[bear]]. ''[[Big-game hunting|Big game]]'' is a term sometimes used interchangeably with large game although in other contexts it refers to large, typically African, [[mammal]]s (specifically "[[big five game]]" or "dangerous game") which are hunted mainly for trophies in [[safari]]s.
== By continent and region == The type and range of animals hunted for food varies in different parts of the world. This is influenced by [[climate]], animal diversity, local taste and locally accepted views about what can or cannot be legitimately hunted. Sometimes a distinction is also made between varieties and species of a particular animal, such as [[wild turkey]] and [[domestic turkey]]. Fish caught for sport are referred to as [[game fish]]. The flesh of the animal, when butchered for consumption is often described as having a "gamey" flavour. This difference in taste can be attributed to the wild diet of the animal, which usually results in a lower fat content compared to domestic farm raised animals.
In some countries, game is classified, including legal classification with respect to licences required, as either "small game" or "large game". A single small game licence may cover all small game species and be subject to yearly [[bag limits]]. Large game are often subject to individual licensing where a separate licence is required for each individual animal taken (tags).
=== Africa === {{See also|Elephant meat}} [[File:American big-game hunting; (1901) (18117144345).jpg|alt=|thumb|Big game hunting]] In some parts of [[Africa]], wild animals hunted for their meat are called [[bushmeat]]; see that article for more detailed information on how this operates within the economy (for personal consumption and for money) and the law (including [[overexploitation]] and illegal imports). Animals hunted for bushmeat include, but are not limited to: * Various species of [[antelope]], including [[duiker]]s * Various species of [[primates]] like [[mandrill]]s or [[gorilla]]s * [[Rodent]]s like [[porcupine]]s or [[cane rat]]s Some of these animals are endangered or otherwise protected, and thus it is illegal to hunt them.
In Africa, animals hunted for their pelts or [[ivory]] are sometimes referred to as the ''big game''.
Also see the legal definition of game in Swaziland.<ref>[http://www.sntc.org.sz/legislat/gameact.html The Game Act] Swaziland Legislation</ref>
==== South Africa ==== [[South Africa]] is a famous destination for game hunting, with its large biodiversity and therefore rather impressive variety of game species. Many creatures have returned to former areas from which they were once taken from as a result of being killed for big game hunting. Species of [[Animal|creatures]] commonly hunted include: {{div col|colwidth=20em}} * [[Springbok]] * [[Impala]] * [[Steenbok]] * [[Oribi]] * [[Bushbuck]] * [[Nyala]] * [[Greater Kudu]] * [[Common Eland]] * [[Blue Wildebeest]] * [[Black Wildebeest]] * [[Blesbok]] * [[Bontebok]] * [[Sable Antelope]] * [[Roan Antelope]] * [[Gemsbok]] * [[Giraffe]] * [[Cape Buffalo]] * [[Southern White Rhinoceros]] * [[Plains Zebra]] {{div col end}}
South Africa also has 62 species of gamebirds, including guineafowl, francolin, partridge, quail, sandgrouse, duck, geese, snipe, bustard and korhaan. Some of these species are no longer hunted, and of the 44 indigenous gamebirds that can potentially be utilised in South Africa, only three, namely the [[yellow-throated sandgrouse]], [[Delegorgue's pigeon]] and the [[African pygmy goose]] warrant special protection. Of the remaining 41 species, 24 have shown an increase in numbers and distribution range in the last 25 years or so. The status of 14 species appears unchanged, with insufficient information being available for the remaining three species. The gamebirds of South Africa where the population status in 2005 was secure or growing are listed below: {{div col|colwidth=20em}} * [[Helmeted guineafowl]] * [[Greywing partridge]] * [[Redwing partridge]] * [[Orange River partridge]] * [[Cape francolin]] * [[Natal francolin]] * [[Swainson's francolin]] * [[Common quail]] * [[Harlequin quail]] * [[Namaqua sandgrouse]] * [[Double-banded sandgrouse]] * [[Burchell's sandgrouse]] * [[White-faced duck]] * [[Egyptian goose]] * [[Yellow-billed duck]] * [[Red-billed teal]] * [[Cape shoveller]] * [[Southern pochard]] * [[Knob-billed duck]] * [[Spur-winged goose]] {{div col end}}
===Oceania=== ==== Australia ====
In [[Australia]], game includes: {{div col|colwidth=20em}} * [[Deer]] and [[sambar (deer)|sambar]] * [[Duck]] * [[Magpie goose|Magpie geese]] * [[Dingo]] * [[European rabbit]] * [[Feral cat]] * [[Red fox]] * [[Feral pig|Wild pig]] * [[Wild goat]] * [[Kangaroo]] * [[Emu]] * [[Crocodile]] (Saltwater and Freshwater) * [[Water buffalo|Feral buffalo]] * [[Banteng]] ("Scrub bull") * [[Australian feral camel|Feral camel]] * [[Brumby|Australian feral horse]] * [[Quail]] * [[Wild bull]] * [[Blackbuck]] * [[Feral donkeys in Australia|Feral donkey]] * [[Feral dog]] {{div col end}}
==== New Zealand ==== {{Main|Hunting in New Zealand}} Game in [[New Zealand]] includes: * [[Chamois]] * [[Deer]], multiple species * [[Pig]] * [[Tahr]] * [[Duck]], multiple species
===North America=== ==== Canada and the United States ==== {{See also|Upland game bird|country food}} In the [[United States|U.S.]] and [[Canada]], [[white-tailed deer]] are the most commonly hunted big game. Other game species include:
[[File:Virginia-Wachtel 2007-06-16 059.jpg|thumb|right|Bobwhite quail, an important North American gamebird]] [[File:White-tailed deer.jpg|thumb|right|White-tailed deer]] {{div col|colwidth=20em}} {{no col break|
===== Reptiles and amphibians ===== {{See also|Alligator meat}} * [[American alligator]] * [[American bullfrog]] * [[Common snapping turtle]] * [[Rattlesnake]] }} {{no col break|
===== Birds (predator) ===== * [[Crow]] * [[Brown-headed cowbird|Cowbird]] * [[Raven]] }} {{no col break|
===== Birds (galliforms) ===== * [[Dove]] (non-galliform) * [[Chukar partridge]] * [[Grouse]] * [[Partridge]] * [[Pheasant]] * [[Lagopus|Ptarmigan]] * [[Quail]] * [[Turkey (bird)|Turkey]] }} {{no col break|
===== Birds (waterfowl) ===== * [[Duck]] * [[Goose]] }} {{no col break|
===== Birds (waders) ===== * [[Snipe]] * [[Woodcock]] }} {{no col break|
===== Ungulates ===== * [[American Bison]] * [[Bighorn Sheep]] * [[Dall sheep]] * [[White-tailed deer]] * [[Elk]] * [[Moose]] * [[Pronghorn]] * [[Reindeer]] * [[Wild boar]] }} {{no col break|
===== Carnivores ===== * [[American black bear]] * [[Bobcat]] * [[Coyote]] * [[Fox]] * [[Grizzly bear]] * [[Cougar]] * [[Raccoon]] }} {{no col break|
===== Rodents ===== * [[Beaver]] * [[Coypu|River rat]] * [[Muskrat]] * [[Squirrel]] }}
{{no col break|
===== Misc. mammals ===== * [[Hare]] * [[Rabbit]] * [[Opossum]] }} {{div col end}}
===Asia===
==== People's Republic of China ==== In the PRC there is a special cuisine category called [[ye wei]], which includes animals in the wild.
==== Russia ==== {{See also|Hunting in Russia}} [[File:Wassilij Grigorjewitsch Perow 004.jpg|thumb|right|"The Hunters at Rest" by [[Vasily Perov]], 1871]] {{div col|colwidth=20em}} * [[Anser (bird)|Anser]] * [[Beaver]] * [[Black grouse]] * [[Brown bear]] * [[Common quail]] * [[Deer]] * [[Duck]] * [[European hare]] * [[Fox]] * [[Ground squirrel]] * [[Goose]] * [[Hazel grouse]] * [[Eurasian lynx]] * [[Mountain hare]] * [[Perdix]] * [[Pheasant]] * [[Rabbit]] * [[Raven]] * [[Siberian ibex]] * [[Squirrel]] * [[Wild boar]] * [[Woodcock]] {{div col end}}
===Europe===
==== United Kingdom ==== [[File:Game birds Borough Market.jpg|thumb|Game birds at [[Borough Market]] in [[London]]]] In the [[United Kingdom|UK]] game is defined in [[law]] by the [[Game Act 1831]]. It is illegal to shoot game on Sundays or at night. Other (non-game birds) that are hunted for food in the UK are specified under the [[Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981]]. UK law defines game as including: * [[Black grouse]] (No longer hunted due to decline in numbers) * [[Red grouse]] * [[European hare|Brown hare]] * [[rock ptarmigan|Ptarmigan]] * [[Grey partridge]] and [[red-legged partridge]] * [[Common pheasant]]
[[Deer]] are not included in the definition, but similar controls provided to those in the Game Act apply to deer (from the [[Deer Act 1991]]). Deer hunted in the UK are: * [[Red deer]] * [[Roe deer]] * [[Fallow deer]] * [[Sika deer]] * [[Muntjac deer]] * [[Chinese water deer]] * and [[Hybrid (biology)|hybrids]] of these deer
Other animals which are hunted in the UK include: * [[Duck]], including [[mallard]], [[tufted duck]], [[Common teal|teal]], [[Northern pintail|pintail]] and [[Common pochard|pochard]] * [[Goose]], including [[greylag goose]], [[Canada goose]], [[pink-footed goose]] and in [[England]] and [[Wales]] [[white-fronted goose]] * [[Woodpigeon]] * [[Eurasian woodcock|Woodcock]] * [[Common snipe|Snipe]] * [[Rabbit]] * [[Eurasian golden plover|Golden plover]]
[[Capercaillie]] are not currently hunted in the [[United Kingdom|UK]] because of a recent decline in numbers and conservation projects towards their recovery. The ban is generally considered voluntary on private lands, and few birds live away from [[RSPB]] or [[Forestry Commission]] land allegedly.
{{See also|Hunting and shooting in the United Kingdom}}
==== Iceland ====
In [[Iceland]] game includes: * [[Reindeer]] * [[rock ptarmigan|Ptarmigan]], a popular [[Christmas dish]] in Iceland * [[Puffin]] * [[Auk]] * [[Goose]] * [[Mallard]]
==== Nordic countries ==== [[File:Kopf eines Rehs (Capreolus capreolus).jpg|thumbnail|Roe deer]] Game in [[Norway]], [[Sweden]], [[Denmark]] and [[Finland]] includes: {{div col|colwidth=20em}} * [[Moose]], ''Alces alces''. Moose hunting season in October is close to a [[national pastime]]. * [[Fallow deer]] * [[Red deer]] * [[Roe deer]] * Wild [[reindeer]] * [[Mountain hare]] * [[Boar]] in Denmark and southern Sweden. (Once hunted to extinction, boars were re-introduced in the late 20th century and are now considered a pest by farmers, but an asset by hunters.) * [[Rock ptarmigan]] * [[Willow ptarmigan]] * [[Mallard]] * [[Auk]] in Norway * [[Black grouse]] * [[Woodcock]] * [[Common pheasant]] * [[Common wood pigeon]] * [[Goose]] {{div col end}}
== Preparation == {{Refimprove section|date=July 2007}} [[File:Attributed to Frans Hals, 1625-1630, A Kitchen Interior with a Maid and a Lady Preparing Game.jpg|thumb|A kitchen interior with a maid and a lady preparing game, c. 1600]] Game meat is typically taken from a wild animal that has been shot with a gun or bow. Hunters must be absolutely certain of their target before shooting and should make every effort to get the animal down as quickly and painlessly as possible. Once obtained, game meat{{Clarify|date=May 2010}} must be processed. The method of processing varies by game species and size. Small game and fowl may simply be carried home to be [[butcher]]ed. Large game such as deer is quickly [[field dressing (hunting)|field-dressed]] by removing the [[viscera]] in the field, while very large animals like moose may be partially butchered in the field because of the difficulty of removing them intact from their habitat. Commercial processors often handle deer taken during deer seasons, sometimes even at supermarket meat counters. Otherwise the hunter handles butchering. The carcass is kept cool to minimize spoilage.
Traditionally, game meat used to be hung until "high", i.e. approaching a state of decomposition. The term "gamey" / "gamy" refers to this usually desirable taste (''haut goût'').{{citation needed|reason=Certain meats are referred to as tasting gamey even when fresh.|date=September 2016}} However, this adds to the risk of contamination. Small game can be processed essentially intact, after gutting and skinning or defeathering (by species). Small animals are ready for cooking, although they may be disjointed first. Large game must be processed by techniques commonly practiced by commercial butchers.
== Cooking == {{Cookbook|Game}} Generally game is cooked in the same ways as farmed meat.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gametoeat.co.uk/index.php |title=Game-to-Eat |date=2007-05-02}}</ref> Because some game meat is leaner than store-bought beef, overcooking is a common mishap which can be avoided if properly prepared.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://exoticmeatsales.com/product-info-.html |title=About Game Meat |date=2007-05-19 |accessdate=2011-10-17 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070519220238/http://exoticmeatsales.com/product-info-.html |archivedate=2007-05-19}}</ref><ref>[http://www.highlandgame.com/ Venison Direct to Your Door] Highland Game</ref> It is sometimes [[Grilling|grilled]] or cooked longer or by [[slow cooking]] or moist-heat methods to make it more tender, since some game tends to be tougher than farm-raised meat. Other methods of tenderizing include [[marinade|marinating]] as in the dish [[Hasenpfeffer]], cooking in a [[game pie]] or as a stew such as [[Burgoo]].
== Safety == The [[Norwegian Food Safety Authority]] considers that children, pregnant women, fertile-aged women, and people with high blood pressure should not consume game shot with lead-based ammunition more than once a month. Children who often eat such game might develop a slightly lower IQ, as lead influences the development of the [[central nervous system]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nrk.no/trondelag/barn-far-lavere-iq-av-storviltkjott-1.11209475|title=Mattilsynet: – Barn kan få lavere IQ av storvilt|publisher=NRK.no|language=Norwegian|accessdate=August 30, 2013}}</ref>
== See also == {{portal|Meat|Food}} {{div col|colwidth=20em}} * [[Animal trapping]] * [[Big game hunting]] * [[British Association for Shooting and Conservation]] * [[Bushfood]], something quite different * [[Bushmeat]] * [[Endangered species]] * [[Fishing]] * [[Game & Wildlife Conservation Trust]] * [[Game drive system]] * [[Hunter-gatherer]] * [[French horn|Hunting horn]] * [[Hunting and shooting in the United Kingdom]] * [[Hunting]] * [[Legislation on Hunting with Dogs]] * [[Ornithology]] * [[Overfishing]] * [[Persistence hunting]] * [[Taxidermy]], the preserving of an animal's body for the purpose of display or study * [[Waterfowl hunting]] * [[Wildlife]] * [[World Hunting Association]]
{{div col end}}
== References == {{Reflist|30em|refs = [https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.TheAppMedia.DeerHunter Deer Hunting Game]}}
== External links == * {{Commons category-inline|Game birds}} * [https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.lasthope.wild.animal.hunting Animal Hunting]
