page.title: The State of the World's Children

revision.comment: /* top */HTTP→HTTPS for [[The New York Times]]. using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''The State of the World's Children''''' is an annual report published by the [[United Nations Children's Emergency Fund]] (UNICEF). It is the flagship publication of the organization.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.unicef.org/sowc/ |title=The State of the World's Children reports}}</ref> The first report was published in 1980, having been introduced by [[James P. Grant]] (the executive director of UNICEF at the time).<ref name="1980_1995">{{cite web |url=http://www.unicef.org/about/history/index_sowc.html |title=State of the World's Children (1980-1995)}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/01/30/obituaries/james-p-grant-unicef-chief-and-aid-expert-is-dead-at-72.html |author=Barbara Crossette |date=January 30, 1995 |title=James P. Grant, Unicef Chief And Aid Expert, Is Dead at 72|publisher = ''[[New York Times]]''}}</ref> Peter Adamson was the author of the report for 15 years.<ref name="jim_grant_book">{{cite book |title=Jim Grant: UNICEF Visionary |author1=Peter Adamson |author2=Carol Bellamy |author3=Kul Gautam |author4=Richard Jolly |author5=Nyi Nyi |author6=Mary Racelis |author7=Richard Reid |author8=Jon Rohde |year=2001 |url=http://www.unicef.org/publications/index_4402.html |publisher=UNICEF Innocenti Research Centre}}</ref> The publication of the 1982–1983 ''The State of the World's Children'' report marked the start of the [[child survival revolution]].<ref name="fifield">{{cite book |title=A Mighty Purpose: How Jim Grant Sold the World on Saving Its Children |year= 2015 |publisher=Other Press|first=Adam |last=Fifield}}</ref>{{rp|95}}
Following the end of Grant's tenure at UNICEF and his death in 1995, ''The State of the World's Children'' has received significantly less attention.<ref name=fifield/>{{rp|390}}
==Content==
''The State of the World's Children 1982–1983'' launches the [[child survival revolution]] and pushed for [[GOBI]] (growth monitoring, [[oral rehydration therapy]], breastfeeding, and immunization).<ref name="1980_1995"/>
The 1988 report argues for the need of a "Grand Alliance" for children between governments, schools, mass media, etc., to continue the child survival and development revolution.<ref name="1980_1995"/>
The 1991 report features the [[World Summit for Children]], which happened the previous year. The report covers the commitment made by the Summit and serves as a record.<ref name="1980_1995"/>
The 2015 ''The State of the World's Children'' report, titled ''Reimagine the Future'', reviews the work on children's health and rights in the world in the context of the 25th anniversary of the [[Convention on the Rights of the Child]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.unicef.org/publications/files/SOWC_2015_Summary_and_Tables.pdf |title=THE STATE OF THE WORLD’S CHILDREN 2015: Executive Summary |publisher=UNICEF}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.crop.org/OtherResources/FurtherReading/UNICEF-The-State-of-the-Worlds-Children-in-Numbers-.aspx |title=UNICEF: The State of the World’s Children in Numbers |date=August 24, 2015 |accessdate=May 4, 2016}}</ref> The report also argued that more innovation is necessary, and highlighted examples including Solar Ear (a solar-rechargeable [[hearing aid]] battery charger) and community-based management of acute malnutrition.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://reliefweb.int/report/world/state-world-s-children-2015-reimagine-future-innovation-every-child |title=The State of the World’s Children 2015: Reimagine the future - Innovation for every child |date = November 20, 2014 |publisher=reliefweb |accessdate=May 4, 2016}}</ref>
==See also==
* [[Timeline of global health]]
==References==

{{Infobox person | name = Tomaž Humar | birth_date = {{Birth date|1969|02|18|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Ljubljana]], [[SR Slovenia]], [[Yugoslavia]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2009|11|10|1969|02|18|mf=yes}} | death_place = [[Langtang Lirung]], [[Nepal]] | occupation = [[Mountaineering|Mountaineer]] | children = 2 | website = [https://web.archive.org/web/19991008131526/http://www.humar.com/ www.humar.com] }} '''Tomaž Humar''' (February 18, 1969 – [[Circa|c.]] November 10, 2009), nicknamed '''Gozdni Joža'''<ref name="nickname">{{cite news | url = http://www.rtvslo.si/sport/preostali-sporti/zivljenje-tomaza-humarja-se-je-koncalo-na-gori/216869 | title = Življenje Tomaža Humarja se je končalo na gori |trans-title=Tomaž Humar's life ended on the mountain | author = T. K. B., R. K. | publisher = [[Radiotelevizija Slovenija|RTV Slovenija]] | date = 14 November 2009 | accessdate = 25 November 2013 | language = Slovenian }}</ref> (akin to [[Hillbilly]]), was a [[Slovenia]]n [[mountaineering|mountaineer]]. A father of two, Humar lived in [[Kamnik]], [[Slovenia]]. He completed over 1500 ascents, and won a number of mountaineering and other awards, including the [[Piolet d'Or]] in 1996 for his [[Ama Dablam]] ascent.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dhaulagiri.extremekanal.com/himal/amadab/amadabl.htm |title=Ama Dablam, Tomaz Humar, Himalaya Extreme, ultimate climbing page |publisher=Dhaulagiri.extremekanal.com |date= |accessdate=2009-11-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091118174849/http://dhaulagiri.extremekanal.com/himal/amadab/amadabl.htm |archivedate=2009-11-18 |df= }}</ref>
He became widely recognized in 1999 after his famous solo ascent of the south face of [[Dhaulagiri]],<ref name="rockclimbing">{{cite web|url=http://www.rockclimbing.com/photos/Alpine/Tomaz_Humar_Soloing_on_the_South_Face_of_Dhaulagirl_7948.html |title=Tomaz Humar Soloing on the South Face of Dhaulagirl |publisher=Rockclimbing.com |date=2002-10-19 |accessdate=2009-11-14}}</ref> considered one of the deadliest routes in the [[Himalaya]]s with a 40% fatality rate.<ref name="fotopedia">{{cite web|url=http://www.fotopedia.com/albums/IHUrDNu8hTk/entries/1KBYuivKOd0 |title=Nepal - Annapurnas, Dhaulagiri and Mustang area |publisher=Fotopedia.com |date=2008-10-07 |accessdate=2009-11-14}}</ref>
During a solo attempt to climb [[Nanga Parbat]] in 2005, Humar became trapped by avalanches and melting snow at an altitude of nearly 6000 meters.<ref name="climbing.com">{{cite web|last=MacDonald |first=Dougald |url=http://www.climbing.com/news/hotflashes/humartrapped/ |title=Humar Trapped on Nanga Parbat |publisher=Climbing.com |date= |accessdate=2009-11-14}}</ref> After six days in a [[snow cave]] he was rescued by a [[Pakistan Army]] helicopter crew on August 10, 2005: Lieutenant Colonel Rashid Ulah Baig and Major Khalid Amir Rana.<ref name="everestnews">{{cite web|url=http://www.everestnews.com/pak2005/nphumar2005u08122005.htm |title=Tomaz Humar Rescued from Nanga Parbat |publisher=Everestnews.com |year=2005 |accessdate=2009-11-14}}</ref>
On October 28, 2007, Humar reached the Eastern summit of [[Annapurna I]] (8091 m) via a route at the far eastern end of the South Face.<ref name="russianclimb">{{cite web|url=http://www.russianclimb.com/humar_annapurna.html |title=Tomas Humar: New Alpine Solo Route on the South Face of Annapurna |publisher=Russianclimb.com |date=October 2007 |accessdate=2009-11-14}}</ref><ref name="bergsteigen">{{cite web|url=http://www.bergsteigen.at/de/bericht.aspx?ID=12687 |title=Tomaz Humar klettert solo durch die Annapurna Südwand |publisher=Bergsteigen.at |date=2007-11-22 |accessdate=2009-11-14}}</ref>
On November 9, 2009, Humar, who was on a solo climb via the South Face of [[Langtang Lirung]] (last climbed in 1995<ref name="SummitPost">{{cite web|url=http://www.summitpost.org/mountain/rock/153976/langtang-lirung.html |title=Langtang Lirung |publisher=SummitPost |date=2007-09-18 |accessdate=2009-11-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080517135252/http://www.summitpost.org/mountain/rock/153976/langtang-lirung.html |archivedate=May 17, 2008 }}</ref>), had an accident during the descent.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.everestnews.com/stories2009/tumreport1102009.htm | title = Tomaz Humar Stuck on Langtang Lirung with broken leg?? | publisher = www.everestnews.com}}</ref> His only contact with the base camp staff via a [[satellite phone]] was made on the day of the accident and he appeared to be in critical condition with leg, spine and rib injuries. He was stuck on the mountain at an elevation of approximately 6,300 meters for several days before his body was found on November 14, 2009 at an elevation of 5,600 meters.<ref name="topnews">{{cite web|last=Manchanda |first=Sukhpreet |url=http://www.topnews.in/slovenian-climber-dies-himalayas-2236059 |title=Slovenian climber dies in Himalayas |publisher=Topnews.in |date=2007-08-19 |accessdate=2009-11-14}}</ref>
==Prominent expeditions== [[File:Langtang Lirung.jpg|thumb|left|Langtang Lirung]] *13. November 1994: [[Ganesh V]] (6770 m), in [[Ganesh Himal]], new variation on SE face, with Stane Belak-Šrauf *6. May 1995: [[Annapurna]] (8091 m), N face, French Route, solo climb (the only traditional expedition in which he participated) *4. May 1996: [[Ama Dablam]] (6828 m), new route on NW face, with [[Vanja Furlan]] *2. November 1996: [[Bobaye]] (6808 m), 1st ascent of the summit, NW face, new route "Golden Heart", solo climb *1. October 1997: [[Lobuche]] East (6119 m), NE face, new route "Talking About Tsampa", with Janez Jeglič and [[Carlos Carsolio]] *9-11. October 1997: [[Pumori]] (7165 m), SE face attempt of new route up to 6300 m - then after participation in rescue action at N reached the summit by normal route), with Janez Jeglič, Marjan Kovač *31. October 1997: [[Nuptse]] West top (NW, 7742 m), W face, new route, with [[Janez Jeglič]] (who died during descent) *26. October 1998: [[El Capitan]] (2307 m) ([[Yosemite]]), route Reticent Wall A4-A5, 3rd solo climb (1st solo by non-American) *2. November 1999: [[Dhaulagiri]] (8167 m), new route on S face (up to 8000 m, without reaching the top), solo climb *26. October 2002: [[Shisha Pangma]], (8046 m), with Maxut Zhumaiev, Denis Urubko, Aleksej Raspopov, Vassiliy Pivtsov *June 2003: Nanga Parbat (8125 m), his first attempt to climb [[Rupal face|Rupal (S) Face]], up to ca. 6000 m *22. December 2003: [[Aconcagua]] (6960 m), S face, new route with [[Aleš Koželj]] *October 2004: [[Jannu]] (7711 m), E face, attempt solo up to 7000 m *23. April 2005: [[Cholatse]] (6440 m), NE face 2nd ascent with new variation, with Aleš Koželj, Janko Oprešnik *Aug 2005: [[Nanga Parbat]] (8125 m), attempt to solo climb Rupal (S) Face, up to 7000 meters (with famous helicopter rescue action - see main text above) *October 2006: [[Baruntse]] (7129 m), W face of SE ridge, solo *28. October 2007: [[Annapurna]] (8091 m), S face, new route, solo climb * (ca.) 8. November 2009: [[Langtang Lirung]] (7227 m), S face solo attempt, died during descent
==Bibliography== * Tomaz Humar: ''Black Rock. The Northwest Face of Bobaye''. "American Alpine Journal", Vol. 1997, pp. 17–18 * Tomaz Humar: ''Nuptse West Face''. "American Alpine Journal", Vol. 1998, pp. 3–10 * Tomaž Humar: ''Ni nemogočih poti''. Mobitel, Ljubljana 2001. ({{ISBN|961-6403-23-0}}) {{COBISS|ID=112438016}} {{sl icon}}, 207 pages * Tomaž Humar: ''No Impossible Ways'' (transl. Tamara Soban). Mobitel, Ljubljana 2001. ({{ISBN|961-6403-23-0}}), 104 pages
==Further reading== * Bernadette McDonald (2008). ''Tomaž Humar''. Hutchinson, London, UK. ({{ISBN|9780091795474}})
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20050810000715/http://www.humar.com/en/index.php Tomaž Humar website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100219234524/http://www.humar.com/en/expeditions/expeditions.php Tomaž Humar website: Expeditions] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20091209094307/http://www.nationalgeographic.com/adventure/0512/features/tomaz_humar.html National Geographic on incredible Nanga Parbat rescue] *[http://www.alpinismonline.com/alp-notas.asp?id=10189&lang=EN Tomaž Humar dies in Langtang Lirung ] *[http://www.explorehimalaya.com/blog/unusual-rescue-by-fishtail-air-helicopter/ Tomaž Humar final rescue attempt] *[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/sport-obituaries/6608092/Tomaz-Humar.html Tomaz Humar] - Daily Telegraph obituary *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120415015304/http://www.climbing.com/news/passages/tomaz_humar_dies_on_langtang_lirung/ Tomaz Humar Dies on Langtang Lirung] - Climbing Magazine detailed obituary by Dougald MacDonald
{{Authority control}}

'''WebPT''' is a [[Phoenix, Arizona]]-based company that provides [[web-based]] [[electronic medical record]] (EMR) systems for [[physical therapists]].<ref name="Inc. Top 10">{{cite web|last1=Henry|first1=Zoe|title=The 10 Fastest-Growing Private Companies in Phoenix|url=http://www.inc.com/zoe-henry/10-fastest-growing-companies-in-phoenix.html|website=Inc.com|publisher=Inc.|accessdate=6 March 2015}}</ref><ref name="Phoenix BJ 5/18/12">{{cite web|last1=O'Grady|first1=Patrick|title=WebPT carves niche in electronic medical records for therapists|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/phoenix/print-edition/2012/05/18/webpt-carves-niche-in-electronic.html?page=all|website=Phoenix Business Journal|publisher=Phoenix Business Journal|accessdate=6 March 2015|ref=Phoenix Business Journal}}</ref> In addition to its patient documentation software, WebPT offers systems for billing, [[scheduling]], and [[practice management]].<ref name="Phoenix BJ 5/18/12" /> As of February 2015, more than 43,000 rehabilitation professionals in over 7,000 clinics used WebPT’s system.<ref name="WebPT home page">{{cite web|title=WebPT: The ultimate EMR for physical therapists|url=http://www.webpt.com|website=WebPT.com|publisher=WebPT|accessdate=6 March 2015}}</ref>
WebPT was named to the [[Inc. (magazine)|Inc.]] 500 list of the "fastest-growing private U.S. companies" in 2013 and 2014.<ref name="Inc. 5000 2014">{{cite web|title=WebPT Inc. 5000|url=http://www.inc.com/profile/webpt|website=Inc.com|publisher=Inc.|accessdate=6 March 2015|ref=Inc. 5000}}</ref> From 2011 to 2013, the company was named one of the "Best Places to Work in the Valley" by the Phoenix Business Journal.<ref name="PBJ 2011 Best Places">{{cite web|title=2011 Best Places to Work in the Valley Awards Luncheon|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/phoenix/event/38561|website=Phoenix Business Journal|publisher=Phoenix Business Journal|accessdate=6 March 2015|ref=Phoenix Business Journal}}</ref><ref name="PBJ 2012 Best Places">{{cite web|title=Best Places to Work 2012|url=http://assets.bizjournals.com/phoenix/pdf/Best%20Places%20to%20Work%202012-new.pdf|website=Phoenix Business Journal|publisher=Phoenix Business Journal|accessdate=6 March 2015|ref=Phoenix Business Journal}}</ref><ref name="PBJ Best Places 2013">{{cite web|title=Best Places to Work 2013|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/phoenix/event/77851#eventDetails|website=Phoenix Business Journal|publisher=Phoenix Business Journal|accessdate=6 March 2015|ref=Phoenix Business Journal}}</ref> In October 2014, the company reported a three-year growth rate of 1,316 percent, making it the fastest-growing company in Phoenix.<ref name="Inc. Top 10" />
==History== WebPT was founded in 2008 by Heidi Jannenga and her ex-husband, Brad Jannenga.<ref name="Phoenix BJ 5/18/12" /> Heidi had a physical therapy practice, which helped spark the idea for the software.<ref name="Phoenix BJ 5/18/12" /> Brad was once president and CTO and now Heidi is the president after Battery Ventures voted to remove Brad from his executive role. Nancy Ham is CEO.<ref name="WebPT About">{{cite web|title=WebPT: About|url=http://www.webpt.com/about|website=WebPT|publisher=WebPT|accessdate=6 March 2015|ref=WebPT}}</ref>
In 2010, the [[Startup company|startup]] received a $1 million funding round from Canal Partners, led by Jim Armstrong.<ref name="Forbes 10.12">{{cite news|last1=Wagner|first1=Eric T.|title=Match.com Hatches a Marriage, Baby and $9 Million Dollar Company|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/ericwagner/2012/10/09/match-com-hatches-a-marriage-baby-and-9-million-dollar-company/|accessdate=6 March 2015|work=Forbes|publisher=Forbes|date=9 October 2012|ref=Forbes}}</ref> WebPT received an undisclosed investment in June 2014 from [[venture capital]] firm [[Battery Ventures]].<ref name="PBJ 9 July 2014" />
To expand its billing system, WebPT acquired Health Data Solutions in 2012, a revenue cycle management business that provided billing services primarily to physical therapists and [[chiropractors]].<ref name="PBJ 15 June 2012">{{cite news|last1=O'Grady|first1=Patrick|title=WebPT buys Health Data Solutions, expands billing market|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/phoenix/news/2012/06/15/webpt-buys-health-data-solutions.html|accessdate=6 March 2015|work=Phoenix Business Journal|publisher=Phoenix Business Journal|date=15 June 2012|ref=Phoenix Business Journal}}</ref> WebPT acquired WebOutcomes, an online outcomes tracking tool offering [[evidence-based]] tests that physical and [[occupational therapists]] use to collect objective patient data, in November 2014.<ref name="PBJ 4 Nov 14">{{cite news|last1=Ringle|first1=Hayley|title=WebPT stretches closer to becoming SalesForce of physical therapy with latest acquisition|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/phoenix/blog/techflash/2014/11/webpt-stretches-closer-to-becoming-salesforce-of.html?page=all|accessdate=6 March 2015|work=Phoenix Business Journal|publisher=Phoenix Business Journal|date=4 November 2014|ref=Phoenix Business Journal}}</ref>
In 2013, WebPT launched the WebPT Marketplace, an [[e-commerce]] site with the goal of selling clinical supplies to WebPT customers at reduced rates.<ref name="PBJ 9 July 2014">{{cite news|last1=Ringle|first1=Hayley|title=Phoenix's WebPT looks to hire 150 with new office planned in historic downtown Phoenix building|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/phoenix/blog/techflash/2014/07/phoenixs-webpt-looks-to-hire-150-with-new-office.html?page=all|accessdate=6 March 2015|work=Phoenix Business Journal|publisher=Phoenix Business Journal|date=9 July 2014|ref=Phoenix Business Journal}}</ref> The company announced a partnership with SOLS, a manufacturer of [[3D printing|3D-printed]] foot [[orthotics]], in February 2015.<ref name="PBJ 4 Feb 2015">{{cite news|last1=Ringle|first1=Hayley|title=WebPT steps in with 3-D print foot company|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/phoenix/blog/techflash/2015/02/webpt-steps-in-with-3-d-print-foot-company.html?page=all|accessdate=6 March 2015|work=Phoenix Business Journal|publisher=Phoenix Business Journal|date=4 February 2015|ref=Phoenix Business Journal}}</ref>
